title: Understanding Your Genetic Test Results
description: Comprehensive guide to interpreting genetic test results including positive, negative, and uncertain findings

level1.title: Understanding Your Genetic Test Results
level1.content: Genetic test results can be confusing. This guide will help you understand what different types of results mean. Always discuss your results with a genetic counselor or healthcare provider who can explain what the results mean for you and your family.

level2.title: Interpreting Genetic Test Results
level2.content: Genetic test results are classified based on whether variants (changes in DNA) are detected and their clinical significance. Results may be positive (a disease-causing variant found), negative (no variant found), or uncertain (a variant is found but its significance is unknown). Understanding these classifications helps you work with your healthcare team to make informed decisions about your care and family testing.

level3.title: Variant Classification and Clinical Interpretation
level3.content: Genetic variant interpretation follows ACMG/AMP guidelines that classify variants into five categories: pathogenic, likely pathogenic, variant of uncertain significance (VUS), likely benign, and benign. This classification integrates population frequency data, computational predictions, functional evidence, and clinical observations. The clinical interpretation connects variant classification to patient phenotype and family history to determine actionability.

level4.title: Advanced Concepts in Genetic Result Interpretation
level4.content: Comprehensive result interpretation considers variant classification confidence, penetrance estimates, genotype-phenotype correlations, and the context of testing indication. Variant curation applies evidence-based criteria including population data from gnomAD, computational predictions (REVEL, CADD), functional studies, and segregation analysis. Report review should address testing limitations, residual risk for negative results, and implications for cascade testing.

level5.title: Precision Interpretation: Integrating Evidence for Clinical Action
level5.content: Expert-level interpretation synthesizes variant evidence within Bayesian probability frameworks, accounts for gene-specific considerations (variable penetrance, phenotypic spectrum), and integrates emerging data from ClinVar assertions, functional assays, and literature updates. Ongoing reclassification requires robust recontact protocols. Interpretation challenges include novel variants, genotype-first ascertainment bias, and population database limitations for underrepresented groups.

positiveResults.title: Positive Results (Pathogenic or Likely Pathogenic Variants)

level1.content: A positive result means a genetic change was found that causes or likely causes a health condition. This does not mean you definitely have or will get the condition, but it does mean you have an increased risk. Your healthcare team will discuss what steps you can take for monitoring or prevention.
whatItMeans: A disease-causing genetic change was found
Your risk for the associated condition is increased
It does not always mean you will definitely develop the condition
Screening or preventive steps may be recommended
Family members may want to consider testing
nextSteps: Discuss results with your genetic counselor
Follow up with specialists as recommended

level2.content: A positive result indicates identification of a pathogenic or likely pathogenic variant associated with increased disease risk. For diagnostic testing, this confirms the genetic cause of symptoms. For predictive testing, it identifies elevated risk for future disease development. Management recommendations depend on the specific gene, variant, and individual factors. Medical management may include enhanced surveillance, risk-reducing medications, or surgical options. Cascade testing enables identification of at-risk family members.

pathogenicVsLikelyPathogenic.pathogenic: Greater than 99% certainty the variant causes disease
pathogenicVsLikelyPathogenic.likelyPathogenic: Greater than 90% certainty the variant causes disease

level3.content: Positive result interpretation requires integration of variant classification with clinical context. Penetrance (the probability of developing disease given the variant) varies by gene and may be modified by variant position, family history, and other factors. Evidence-based guidelines (NCCN, ACMG) provide gene-specific management recommendations. Multidisciplinary care coordination ensures appropriate specialist referrals. Documentation of testing and management recommendations facilitates care continuity.
penetranceConsiderations: High penetrance: most carriers develop the condition (e.g., Huntington's disease)
Moderate penetrance: significant increased risk (e.g., BRCA1/2)
Lower penetrance: modestly elevated risk (e.g., some colon cancer genes)
Age-related penetrance: risk increases with age
Sex-specific penetrance: risk differs by sex
clinicalIntegration: Document variant and recommendations in medical record

level4.content: Advanced positive result management considers variant-specific penetrance data, polygenic risk score modification, and emerging therapeutics. Genotype-phenotype correlations guide organ-specific surveillance intensity. Shared decision-making addresses individual values regarding risk-reducing interventions. Cascade testing programs optimize family identification while respecting autonomy. Documentation supports insurance appeals, clinical trial matching, and research opportunities.
advancedConsiderations: PRS integration for refined risk stratification
Emerging targeted therapies and trial eligibility
Insurance navigation and genetic discrimination protections
familyTesting: First-degree relatives have 50% chance of carrying variant
Site-specific testing is lower cost and faster
Barriers include family communication, access, and insurance
Genetic counseling recommended for family members

level5.content: Precision medicine for positive results incorporates multi-gene panel findings, somatic-germline integration in oncology, and dynamic risk models. Variant reclassification protocols ensure patients receive updated information. International data sharing advances variant interpretation and management evidence. Challenges include actionability determination for newly identified genes, health equity in management access, and psychological adaptation to genetic risk.
precisionApproaches: Somatic testing correlation in cancer care
Dynamic risk modeling with biomarkers and imaging

level1.content: A negative result means no disease-causing genetic change was found in the genes tested. This is often reassuring, but it does not mean zero risk. The test may not have looked at all possible genes, or you may have a genetic change that current tests cannot detect. Your family history still matters for your health care.
whatItMeans: No disease-causing variant was found in the genes tested
Does not mean zero risk for the condition
Family history remains important for your care
Further testing may sometimes be recommended
importantConsiderations: What was the reason for testing?
Are there other tests to consider?
How should your care be managed going forward?

level2.content: Negative results interpretation depends on the testing context. A 'true negative' in a family with a known variant significantly reduces risk. An 'uninformative negative' when no family variant is known may not substantially change risk assessment. Test limitations include genes not on the panel, variant types not detected (large deletions, deep intronic), and novel genes not yet associated with disease. Post-test risk assessment integrates residual genetic risk with empiric risk from family history.

negativeResultTypes.trueNegative: Family variant known and not found in patient - significantly reduces risk
negativeResultTypes.uninformativeNegative: No family variant known, no variant found - limited risk reduction
negativeResultTypes.incompleteNegative: Testing limitations may have missed variants

postTestRiskFactors: Pre-test probability based on personal/family history
Proportion of condition caused by tested genes
Possibility of unidentified genes or mechanisms

level3.content: Residual risk calculations quantify the remaining genetic risk after negative testing. Bayesian analysis integrates pre-test probability with test sensitivity to determine post-test probability. Management recommendations for uninformative negatives may still include enhanced surveillance based on family history. Considerations for additional testing include reflex to additional genes, repeat testing with updated panels, or alternative testing methodologies (deletion/duplication analysis, RNA sequencing).
residualRiskConcepts: Pre-test probability from validated risk models
Test sensitivity and detection rate by variant type
Gene coverage for phenotype of interest
additionalTestingConsiderations: Expanded panel testing for additional genes

level4.content: Advanced negative result counseling addresses the limitations of current knowledge, including genes not yet associated with the phenotype, non-coding variants, and complex inheritance. Risk model recalibration for negative testing varies by model and testing comprehensiveness. Documentation should specify genes tested, methodology limitations, and residual risk estimates. Families with strong histories despite negative testing may benefit from research enrollment and longitudinal follow-up.
limitationsToAddress: Genes not yet discovered for the phenotype
Structural variants not detected by sequencing

level5.content: The interpretation of negative results evolves with advancing knowledge. Reanalysis programs systematically update prior negative results as new genes are identified and variant classification criteria are refined. Multi-omic approaches may resolve previously negative cases. Health equity concerns include underrepresentation in databases leading to higher false-negative rates in diverse populations. The psychological impact of diagnostic uncertainty requires ongoing support.
evolvingInterpretation: International data sharing for rare variants

level1.content: Sometimes genetic testing finds a change in your DNA, but scientists are not yet sure if it causes health problems. This is called a variant of uncertain significance or VUS. A VUS should not change your medical care based on genetic testing alone. Your family history remains important, and the VUS may be reclassified in the future as more information becomes available.
keyPoints: Scientists are not yet sure if this change affects health
Should not change medical care based on genetics alone
May be reclassified as more is learned
Family testing may sometimes help clarify significance
whatToExpect: Your genetic counselor will explain the specific VUS
Medical management based on family history, not VUS
You may be contacted if classification changes
Family testing may be offered to help clarify

level2.content: A VUS is a genetic variant with insufficient evidence to classify as pathogenic or benign. VUS are common, especially with multi-gene panel testing and in underrepresented populations. Management should not be altered based on VUS alone; clinical decisions rely on personal and family history. VUS may be reclassified over time as additional data accumulates. Laboratories have reclassification notification policies, and patients may need periodic follow-up.
vusFrequency: More common with larger gene panels
Varies by gene and testing laboratory
Many VUS are ultimately classified as benign
managementPrinciples: Do not alter management based on VUS alone
Clinical decisions based on personal/family history
Document VUS in medical record with classification date
Consider family studies to gather additional evidence

level3.content: VUS classification reflects limited evidence for pathogenicity assessment. Contributing factors include novel variants, variants in less-studied genes, and underrepresentation of diverse populations in reference databases. Evidence for reclassification includes segregation in families, additional case reports, functional studies, and computational prediction refinements. Laboratories use ACMG/AMP criteria with gene-specific modifications. Patients may experience VUS-related distress requiring psychological support.
evidenceForReclassification: Segregation with disease in families (or lack thereof)
Accumulation of cases in databases (ClinVar, literature)
Functional studies demonstrating effect on protein
Population frequency data from diverse cohorts
psychologicalConsiderations: Clear communication about VUS meaning is essential
Provide resources for coping with uncertainty

level4.content: Advanced VUS management includes family segregation studies, research referral for functional characterization, and systematic reclassification monitoring. Hot VUS (variants approaching likely pathogenic threshold) may warrant more conservative management discussions. Gene-specific VUS interpretation guidelines are emerging for well-characterized genes. Challenges include patient anxiety, inappropriate clinical actions, and laboratory variability in classification. Documentation should capture counseling about uncertainty and follow-up plans.
advancedStrategies: Targeted segregation studies in informative families
Hot VUS identification and conservative counseling
reclassificationManagement: Systematic tracking of VUS in patient databases
Periodic query of ClinVar for updates
Documentation of reclassification and updated counseling

level5.content: Contemporary VUS challenges include the proliferation of VUS with expanded testing, disparities in classification for variants from underrepresented populations, and the psychological burden of uncertainty. Emerging solutions include multiplexed functional assays, deep learning variant effect predictors, and international data sharing initiatives. ClinGen expert panels provide definitive classifications for specific genes. The field works toward reducing VUS rates through improved evidence frameworks and diverse population representation.

level1.content: No test is perfect. Sometimes tests give incorrect results. A false positive means the test says there is a problem when there is not. A false negative means the test misses a problem that is actually there. This is why confirmatory testing and clinical judgment are important.

definitions.falsePositive: Test suggests a problem that is not actually present
definitions.falseNegative: Test misses a problem that is actually present

whatYouCanDo: Discuss any positive results with your healthcare team
Ask about confirmatory testing when recommended
Share your family history even if tests are negative
Genetic counseling helps interpret results in context

level2.content: Test accuracy is measured by sensitivity (ability to detect true positives) and specificity (ability to correctly identify negatives). False positive results may occur from technical artifacts, sample issues, or non-pathogenic variants. False negatives result from variants in untested regions, variant types not detected by the methodology, or analytical limitations. Confirmatory testing with an independent sample or methodology addresses technical false positives. Clinical correlation is essential for appropriate result interpretation.
accuracyMetrics: Sensitivity: true positive rate, ability to detect variants
Specificity: true negative rate, ability to avoid false positives
Positive predictive value: probability positive result is true
Negative predictive value: probability negative result is true

falseNegative: Variants in regions not covered by test

level3.content: Quality assurance processes minimize false results, including validation studies, proficiency testing, and clinical correlation. Screening tests (e.g., cell-free DNA) have different performance characteristics than diagnostic tests, requiring confirmation of positive screens. Variant confirmation protocols may include orthogonal methodologies or independent sample analysis. Understanding positive and negative predictive values in the context of pre-test probability enables appropriate result interpretation.

screeningVsDiagnostic.screening: Higher sensitivity, more false positives acceptable, requires confirmation
screeningVsDiagnostic.diagnostic: High sensitivity and specificity, used for clinical decisions

level4.content: Advanced considerations for test accuracy include the impact of sample type and quality, bioinformatics pipeline validation, and variant calling algorithm performance. Challenging genomic regions (pseudogenes, highly homologous sequences, repetitive elements) require specialized approaches. Population-specific variant databases improve specificity by distinguishing pathogenic variants from population polymorphisms. Replication and functional studies support variant pathogenicity assessment.
technicalConsiderations: Challenging genomic regions requiring specialized analysis

level5.content: Emerging technologies and analytical approaches aim to reduce false results through long-read sequencing (resolving complex regions), improved bioinformatics algorithms, and expanded reference populations. Clinical-grade quality metrics guide laboratory accreditation and result confidence reporting. The integration of AI-based variant calling and interpretation requires rigorous validation. Ongoing research addresses the clinical impact of false results and optimal confirmation strategies.

questions: What was the indication for testing?
What variant types can be detected by this test?
What is the clinical context (symptoms, family history)?
What are the limitations of this testing?
What is the residual risk if negative?
What are the recommendations based on these results?
